review: I bought a "basic" TV without internet connectivity due to quality and price and was able to get the TV connected to the internet using this little box that I got for less than $100 dollars. Hook-up is simple: one HDMI cord to the TV and the power cord to the wall and you're ready to go. It's a little hard to type/search using the on-screen keyboard but I think there is a way around that if you have a computer connected via Home Sharing... but I haven't tried it yet.The AppleTV ability to AirPlay anything from an iPhone or Macbook makes it well worth the money just by itself. The tiny box is also not an eyesore and is barely visible when sitting on a dark-colored entertainment center.
author: BMilw

review: I have had this product for some time and am very satisfied with it. However, I don't recall seeing a lot of detailed operational instructions with it. Admittedly, I am one who installs first and reads the instructions later. It is a very easy installation and the quality of the programming such as movies is outstanding. The user interface is easy to navigate and I like the feature where I can see trailers for movies and if I don't have time to watch it now, I just place it in my wish list or queue. They also provide customer and critic's reviews. I am running both Apple TV and Roku 2 XS side by side. I did it because I wanted to see which one was the best overall with the intent to returning one of them. Instead I kept them both. I'll save the Roku evaluation for a little later but they are both very good streaming devices with different user interfaces and slightly different offerings. The quality of streaming HD movies on Apple TV is outstanding. I was pleasantly surprised. There is absolutely no freezing, choppiness (truncation) or any other distractions. I ran out of HDMI ports on the TV (which you must have to ensure the highest picture and sound resolution), so I purchased a HDMI switch to hook both Apple TV and Ruku 2 XS. So depending on which product I use, I just switch back and forth. I would also recommend that you not spend a lot of money on expensive HDMI cables. That is simply a lot of hype. You can buy very good HDMI cables for around $15.00 give or take. Just so you know you must have adequate bandwidth. I run at about 24 Mbps and am using a Linksys Gb router. I feel comfortable saying that you can have half the bandwidth that I have and still have a very satisfying experience.
